document.text: youre going to be modeto see the llM E S -V IK G I N I A N It might be remarked that no- bo.iv dissents from the propo sition that aliens should be counted for the purpose  f the census. Among senators who strong ly urged the unfairness of counting aliens in the ascer tainment of congress district populations was Senator Ty son, of Tennessee. He quoted at lengthj from Mr. Tuckers house address. In introduc ing these quotations, Senator Tyson said I would not Have had the temerity to present this mat ter to the senate but for the fact that I took up this matter with the Hon. St George Auck- er, of Virginia, a member of the house of representatives, who is considered one of the greatest constitutional lawyers of the country, a man who is looked upon in the house as perhaps the outstanding con stitutional lawyer in that body. After concluded the quota tions, Senator Tyson added Mr. President, I have read ex tracts from the address ofRep- resentative Tucker, who is, I know, one of the greatest con stitutional lawyers in the United States, and it is his con sidered opinion that the aliens in the United States should not be counted for the purpose of apportionment of represen tatives. Senator Sackett, of Kerf-  tucky, also made similar use of the Tucker speech and ex tolled the Virginian as one of the nations foremost author- ties on the constitution. Though it does not appear in the record, it is a fact that Senator Moses, Republican, of New Hampshire, approached .Mr. Tucker some time ago and asked him to give him the benefit of his opinion on the question.  This led Mr. Tuck er into an. examination of the constitution, and finally to the preparation of of the speech. It is probable that congress will not heed the Tucker argu ment.. But it is undoubtedly a fact that the address has en gendered doubt in many minds and the debate on the bill is appreciably lengthened in con sequence. Until this measure and the farm bill are out of the way, the administration lead ers ftll not dare to agree to a summer recess.

document.text: years, delights in telling her i story of the surrender which , took place here April 9, 1865, j just 77 years ago Thursday. Aunt Millie, quaint, timid, and full of interest in her white and negro friends, was active for her age until last spring when she was struck by a bolt of lightning while in bed. She now walks with the aid of a eane, keeps house for her only son. Uncle Bob Craig, who has served as janitor at Appomattox High School for several generations. Aunt Millie was 13 at the time of the surrender and was the nurse maid of Charlie Sackett Peers, six month old son of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Peers. Mr. Peers was at the time clerk of the Court of Appomattox and was living near the scene of the surrender. I was walking de floor, patting my baby to sleep, when those yankee soldiers came bustin in Marse Georges house. The soldiers hollered for everybody to leave de house cause the worst battle ever fought was starting right den. Marse George fetched Miss

document.text: Virginia Department of Vocat ional Rehabilitation and the American Heart Association. Charles Elliott, Executive Director of Baptist Hospital, formally signed the mutual agreement, which states that selected staff at the hospital will receive intensive, special ized training in cardiac rehab ilitation. The physicians who will coordinate the program at Virginia Baptist Hospital are DRs. Charles Sackett and Joseph Pond, both of Lynch burg. The Lynchburg facility is the fourth center to be opened in a proposed statewide network of 10 to 12 programs targeted for completion by June 1978. Its purpose is to assist victims of heart attack in returning to optimal life styles. The Virginia Baptist Hospital center will be the first in this Virginia network to be operat ed in conjunction with AMSCO. REHAB, a division of American Sterilizer Company, which services over 70 such cardiac rehabilitation centers in the United States. Dr. Walthall, America Heart Association spokesman, indicat ed that the Comprehensive Cardiac Rehabilitation Project is divided into three phases in-patient, out-patient and home program. The in-patient program involves patient-fam ily education and a carefully monitored low level exercise program for the heart patient. The second phase allows for a more intensive exercise pro gram, continuously monitored by electrocardiograph, primar ily conducted on a treadmill and stationary bicycle ergometer. These exercise therapy sess ions. The last segment involves physician prescribed home exercise program like walking, jogging or bicycling, patterned to individual capabilities.

document.text: Two new directors were el ected Thursday, Jan. 20 at the annual members meeting of Co- operativeBuilding and Loan As sociation, Lynchburg. Members of the Appomattox Chapter, United Daughter of the Confederacy, meeting Thursday evening at Maudes for their annual dinner honoring Confed erate heroes Lee, Jackson and Maury, expressed disappoint ment that the scheduled speak er could not appear, but they were rewarded, otherwise, in the substitute speakers who presented historical papers and facts of interest. Mr. Jerry A. Burke, Appo mattox businessman and retired superintendent of Appomattox schools, found that he could not be present. Three chapter members volunteered to be a part of the evening  Mrs. Rachel F. Lawson, who read an account of Surrender at Appo mattox on April 9, 1865 M rs. Lucille Ferrell, who read an account concerning R . E. Lees mother and Mrs. Wiley Morris, who dipped even further back into history to read the will of General George Washingtons mother. Mrs. Clifford Plunkett, re gistrar for the Va. Division, was in charge of registration of members and guests for the ev ening affair. Mrs. Lawsons paper was a copy of a personal interview she held with Martha Mildred Ste vens Craig, an interview which was printed about 31 years ago. In the account Martha Mildred  Aunt Millie , told of her en counters with Union troops in the old village of Appomattox on April 9, 1865. She was nurse maid to Charles Sackett Peers at the time. Little Charles father, George Peers, was clerk of court. The faithful nursemaid hid herself and the child until the shooting ceased in the village.

document.text: The friends of Mr. Charless H. Sackett will be glad to learn that Judge J. IT. Christian has appoint ed him to fill out the unexpired term of the late Judge Wingfield, which term expires in 1906. The pay of the office depends largely on fees and ranges from 3,000 to 5.000. Mr, Sackett is perhi ps as well quali fied as auy man in Virginia to as- sum the duties of the office. He has served under our veteran clerk Geo. T. Peers as deputy, and there uo doubt received competent instruc tion. One of the leading farmers of the county congratulated ye editor on his efforts iu trying to get some in dustries here aud said whenever the promoters got ready for the ware house he wanted a block of the stock, aud that not only would he sell at it, but he would buy every pound offered or make it bring the market price. This sounds like business. How many more of our farmers will aid in establishing a market at home for our leaf. There is no doubt about haring buyers to attend the sales. The merchants here would be greatly benefited, but we doubt seriously whether they will take hold pf tbe enterprise until its success is assured beyopd any doubt, Unfortunately they are not as pro gressive B8 vve would love to see

document.text: Reb at the Courthouse and donated all proceeds to the ladies Memorial Association. Both Joel Flood and John Sears offered land with that of Sears, located upon a beautiful knoll about a half mile west of the Court House, being the one selected. County Clerk George Peers saw to it that this land was properly deeded to the Association. At the September 1866 meeting, storekeeper Francis Meeks who himself lost a son in the Civil War reported that he had cleared the tract of all brush and briers. Messrs. Conner, Rosser, Bryant, Ab bitt, Morgan, Burnett and Laundrum, using contributed lumber, then were employed to make the number of coffins required. Other prominent county citizens also helped. The digging of nineteen graves fell upon George Peers, Charles Sackett, P. N. Meade, J. W. Webb, Robert R. Kyle, George Abbitt, Edward Hix and Wilmer McLean. These men were then assisted by John W. McKinney, John Sears, William Paris, Robert Sweeney, Tho mas Legrand and Thomas Smith in the disinterrring of the various bodies on Novem ber 30, 1866. On December 1 they were reburied in their new, perma- ment plots. In a brief service that day, Judge Lewis Daniel Isbell made the principal address and Presbyterian min ister G. W. Leyburn conducted the religious services. A neat plank fence was later erected around the wooden markers denoting the final resting place of the 18 Confederate and 1 Union soldier. Todays Confederate Ceme tery has changed but little since its establishment 109 years ago. With ten of its occupants

document.text: Politics Mixed W ith Picnics A dm itted A t S enatorial Probe. Milwaukee.Touches, a hammer and picnics were brought up as part of the campaign expenses of United States Senator Isaac Stephenson in the investigation before the Senatori al committee here. The details were given by Rodney Sackett, one of the Stephenson campaign managers, after Senator W. B. Heyburn, the chairman, said the total expenditure of 107,793 would have to be explained to over come the presumption that it had been wrongfully used. Some of the general items given to Sackett to explain were General ex penses for organizing State, 46,052 Milwaukee county, 11,600 office ex penses, 4,074 telephones, 256 post age, 11,000 sundry bills, 8,662 nomination papers, 40 one man to attend colored picnic, 50 campaign buttons, 702 trip through Ghetto three men, 35 one man to another picnic, 10 touches by two old sol diers, 2 numerous and various touches, 17, and a hammer, 3. The newspaper advertising in the campaign, Sackett said, amounted to 12,696. In one instance Senator Stephenson gave 1,500 for a list of farmers names, paying for them at the rate of one cent a name and an extra one-half cent for each subsequent use of the same names.

document.text: P ROHIBITION cause what may prove to be the first serious rift between the house of representative  .and the White House. Administration leaders in the house sent word to President Hoover that the resolution proposing a joint congressional pro hibition committee Is not likely to pass. It was passed by the senate  three weeks ago and sent to the house rules committee, from which it has never emerged. Speaker Nicholas Longworth admit ted that the leaders of. the house do not believe such a joint committee should be allowed to usurp the func tions of the Independent house com mittee already constituted. Fifty wet menjbers of the house of both political parties pledged them selves at a caucus to .battle to a finish against the forthcoming program of the drys to put tffgger aSd Sharper teeth to the prohibitioh laws.  HOSE radical senators who call themselves Republicans won a de cided victory by forcing the appoint ment of Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin as a member of the pow erful finance committee. Senator  Thomaa of Idaho, generally regular, I also was named a member, the vacan cies filled being those left by the resig nations of Edge and Sackett, now am bassadors. The old line Republicans on the committee ou committees fought hard to keep La Follette from the place, but Senator Smoot, fearing to have the contest carried to the floor of the senate, voted with the Demo crats and radicals for the appoint- ment The finance committee now in cludes 11 Republicans and 8 Demo crats. If La Follette and Couzens of Michigan join forces with the Demo crats, the latter will control the com mittee. in any event It Is no longer bossed by the Eastern Republicans, I N THE course of regular business the senate continued Its work on the tariff measure, dealing especially with woolens and  rayon silks. The committee Investigating lobbying heard some more witnesses concerning ef forts to raise or lower the sugar sched ule, and the name of the President was dragged In several times In a way that brought  sharp rebuke fOT the committee from one witness, H. H. Pike, Jr., a New York sugar broker.
